question.title: Why must my method take an ActionEvent when using this::methodName with addActionListener?
question.body:
I’m working on a simple Swing GUI in Java and have a method addListeners() where I attach an ActionListener to a button like this:

increase.addActionListener(this::increasePoints);

However, this line is marked red in my IDE and won’t compile unless I change the method increasePoints to accept an ActionEvent as a parameter:

    points++;
    textField.setText(Integer.toString(points));
}

Originally, I had:

private void increasePoints() {
    points++;
    textField.setText(Integer.toString(points));
}

My question is: Does it have to be written like this? Is there no cleaner or better way? Why exactly do I have to add an ActionEvent parameter, even if I do not use it?

Any clarification would be greatly appreciated! I’m trying to understand not just how to fix it, but why this is necessary.

Here is the full relevant code:

private void addListeners() {
    increase.addActionListener(this::increasePoints);

    // This version works too:
    // increase.addActionListener(new ActionListener() {
    //     @Override
    //     public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
    //         increasePoints();
    //     }
    // });

    decrease.addActionListener(new ActionListener() {
        @Override
        public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
            decreasePoints();
        }
    });
}

private void increasePoints() {
    points++;
    textField.setText(Integer.toString(points));
}

answers.body:
ActionListener is an interface and its actionPerformed method is declared to take an ActionEvent as a parameter (see https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/24/docs/api/java.desktop/java/awt/event/ActionListener.html, for example).

When you call addActionListener, you need to give it something that implements the ActionListener interface and doing so means providing something that provides an actionPerformed method whose signature looks like that. Actually, since ActionListener is an interface with only one method, you can just provide a reference to a method with the same signature (i.e. one that takes an ActionEvent and returns void) like you did (look up the terms "functional interface" and "single abstract method" for more on this, e.g. https://www.baeldung.com/java-8-functional-interfaces).

You might not be using the ActionEvent for what you're doing, but it carries information about what event happened (like which button was pressed). This would be useful, for example, if you wanted to use the same listener for multiple buttons and needed to distinguish between them when the listener was called.

I don't know what your experience with Java is, but depending on what you need, you might like to look at the material at https://dev.java/learn/ for basics about the language.

The signature of addActionListener method is public void addActionListener(ActionListener l) where ActionListener it is a functional interface (in Java programming language a functional interface it is an interface with a sole method) defining the actionPerformed method accepting one argument of type ActionEvent, the method signature being public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e).

this::increasePoints it is method reference that should be possible to translate to...

new ActionListener() {
    public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
        . . .
    }
}

...therefore the increasePoints method signature must match the signature of actionPerformed method defined by th ActionListener interface.

See other answers - addActionListener requires a signature matching:

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) { ... }

You can simplify this in your code several ways, adding as a lambda is simple change which matches the signature without editing your handler:

increase.addActionListener(event -> increasePoints());

As of JDK22 you can use _ to mark unused lambda arguments:

increase.addActionListener(_ -> increasePoints());

Another option is to add the event parameter to your method and continue to use as addActionListener(this::increasePoints):

private void increasePoints(ActionEvent event) {
